articles.headline: After Condom Remarks, Vatican Confirms Shift
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict XVI acknowledged that the need to prevent disease could outweigh opposition to birth-control devices.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI acknowledged that the need to prevent disease could outweigh opposition to birth-control devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Benedict XVI clearly acknowledged on Tuesday that the need to prevent diseases like AIDS could outweigh the church’s long opposition to the use of condoms.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Partisan Rift Mires Product Safety Database Plan
articles.snippet: The Consumer Product Safety Commission is divided over an online database of potential product problems.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Product Safety Commission is divided over an online database of potential product problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the Consumer Product Safety Commission has gathered a trove of complaints about potentially dangerous products, from cribs to Chinese-made drywall. But for the most part, the information has not been made public because of a federal law that requires a manufacturer’s approval before it can be released.

articles.headline: Fed Debated a Target for Inflation
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve has debated setting a formal inflation target, as well as press briefings to explain its decision-making, minutes of recent meetings show.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve has debated setting a formal inflation target, as well as press briefings to explain its decision-making, minutes of recent meetings show.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Nearly three weeks before they announced a $600 billion effort to shore up the economy, Federal Reserve officials debated whether to adopt formal targets for inflation and long-term interest rates, and whether the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, should “hold occasional press briefings.”

articles.headline: Aggrieved Fliers Ask, ‘What Now?’
articles.snippet: After fees, disappearing amenities, higher fares and full flights, fliers may find tougher security the last straw.
articles.abstract: After fees, disappearing amenities, higher fares and full flights, fliers may find tougher security the last straw.
articles.lead_paragraph: As if air travel could get any worse.

articles.headline: SAP Ordered to Pay Oracle $1.3 Billion
articles.snippet: A federal jury awarded Oracle $1.3 billion in damages in its copyright infringement case.
articles.abstract: A federal jury awarded Oracle $1.3 billion in damages in its copyright infringement case.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A clash of technology titans and two of the most powerful executives in Silicon Valley ended on Tuesday with a $1.3 billion federal jury award against SAP for stealing software from Oracle to try to woo away customers.

articles.headline: Life Expectancy in China Rising Slowly, Despite Economic Surge
articles.snippet: China’s economy has grown rapidly for two decades, but life expectancy there has not kept pace.
articles.abstract: China’s economy has grown rapidly for two decades, but life expectancy there has not kept pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: A quick quiz: Which of the following countries has had the smallest increase in life expectancy since 1990  Bangladesh, China, Pakistan, South Korea or Sudan?

articles.headline: South Koreans and U.S. to Stage a Joint Exercise
articles.snippet: President Obama and South Korea’s president agreed to hold joint military exercises as they struggled to keep a North Korean provocation from escalating into war.
articles.abstract: President Obama and South Korea’s president agreed to hold joint military exercises as they struggled to keep a North Korean provocation from escalating into war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama and South Korea’s president agreed Tuesday night to hold joint military exercises as a first response to North Korea’s deadly shelling of a South Korean military installation, as both countries struggled for the second time this year to keep a North Korean provocation from escalating into war.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Mark McDonald

articles.headline: With a Swagger, Wallets Out, Wall Street Dares to Celebrate
articles.snippet: Signs of personal splurging by traders and executives has rebounded from the doldrums of the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Signs of personal splurging by traders and executives has rebounded from the doldrums of the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exuberance made a comeback this year at Josh Koplewicz’s annual Halloween party. More than 1,000 people packed into a 6,000-square-foot space at the Good Units night club in Manhattan, a substantially larger crowd than in the last several years. The open bar was sponsored by Russian Standard vodka, and Mr. Koplewicz, an investment analyst at Goldman Sachs, was able to snag a big headliner: the hip-hop star Lil’ Kim, who performed dressed in a black cat costume.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Kevin Roose

articles.headline: White House Seeks Chinese Help With N. Korea
articles.snippet: As American officials pressed China, they said that the attack did not appear to be the start of an extended military campaign by North Korea.
articles.abstract: As American officials pressed China, they said that the attack did not appear to be the start of an extended military campaign by North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Wednesday began a broad effort to enlist China to help rein in North Korea in the wake of its deadly attack Tuesday on South Korea.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Martin Fackler
